div.head: Section 4
div.p: § 4 With these things presupposed, the following Catholic conclusion is put forward: General conclusion

No one without mortal sin of theft or plunder and obligation to restitution can take with the intention of keeping for himself any treasure improperly so called, whether it consists in money and coinage, or in vessels of gold or silver, or in furnishings and any other precious things which owners have placed in whatever place, either in a shrine or in a temple or in a tomb or under the earth, however much it may have aged with antiquity, if the owner still survives or any to whom it pertains to succeed by right.

This conclusion is so Catholic and manifest that it needs no proof; rather whoever would dare to deny it will either be foolish or will not escape heresy. And the reason for this conclusion is that those treasures or riches or precious things are another's property having proper owners, either those who placed them in the aforesaid places or ordered them to be placed there or their heirs. But whoever takes or seizes another's property against the owner's will commits theft or indeed plunder if violence is applied. And the owner is said to be unwilling even if he does not object out of fear or shame,
ff. de furtis l. penultima .

Therefore it is mortal sin, first because it is against justice. But everything that is against justice is mortal sin according to
Saint Thomas 2 2ae question 59 .

And also because it is against the divine precept where not only theft properly so called is prohibited but also every illicit usurpation of another's property,
Exodus 20 , and
14, quaestione 5, c. penali , and specifically
c. si quid inuenisti
and
c. Multi , and
quaestione 6, c. 1 , where it is said:
If another's property on account of which there is sin can be returned and is not returned, penance is not done but feigned; but if it is truly done the sin is not remitted unless what was taken is restored . And in
regula peccatum de regulis iuris lib 6 . On these things
Raymundus in summa titulo de furtis §. 9 , where likewise
quid si aliquis
and
panormitanus in capitulo finali de furtis .
Therefore as regards our proposition and the question proposed in the beginning, this responsive conclusion is put forward:

To no man in the world, not even to the king of Spain (which we wish to be said with all reverence that we owe to the royal highness), without the license and free and indeed gracious will of King Inca or his descendants to whom it pertained to succeed in their goods by right according to their laws or custom, is it permitted to inquire or search, to dig or to take treasures or riches or precious things with the intention of keeping them which they buried in tombs and the so-called Guacas with their deceased. If they have done the contrary they will commit mortal sin of theft or plunder, and unless they restore them and do penance for their sin, it will be impossible to be saved. And not only must they repent of the sin of theft or plunder but also of the injury which they inflict especially upon the aforesaid successors or living descendants of theirs whose tombs they violate, derogating from the honor and praise of both (namely) the living and the dead and causing their memory to cease For this also they are bound to make satisfaction to them.
Inca was the appellative name of the kings or rather emperors of the kingdoms of Peru, just as the kings of Egypt were formerly accustomed to be called Pharaohs, then Ptolemies.

The first part of this conclusion is sufficiently clear from what has already been said, namely that the treasures and precious things found in tombs are another's property and thus have owners, namely King Inca who is the legitimate successor and heir of Huayna Capac, and indeed of a great and most prudent king as all Spaniards dwelling in that region confess, who had succeeded many illustrious kings who reigned happily in those kingdoms for nearly nine hundred years. There had also succeeded the aforesaid Huayna Capac another of his sons, namely Atahualpa, in the kingdom which was called Quito, and of this one sons and daughters exist today. Similarly, there survive successors of the petty kings who were subject to the rule of the kings Inca and Atahualpa and had their tombs full of treasures and diverse most precious furnishings. Therefore, without the license of Inca and Atahualpa and the other petty kings having their tombs, it was licit to no one to inquire, search, and take with the intention of keeping for themselves those precious things.
The second part, namely that, if they did the contrary, they would sin mortally with the sin of theft or plunder, is clear.
First because they act against justice.

Second because they inflict injury upon them, taking from the dead and living insofar as it is in them honor and fame which consist in this, that the memory of their dead not be destroyed but live perpetually in the opinions of men. And this is a great interest of both as has been proved through the first and second propositions.
Third because they transgress the divine precept.

Fourth because human laws also prohibit and punish it sharply, namely with the ultimate punishment, as appears in
l. 2 § Diuus Adrianus ff. de sepulchro uiolato , where it is said thus:
Against those who despoil corpses governors are accustomed to intervene more severely, especially if they attack with armed force. So that if they did it armed like bandits they are even punished capitally.
Thus there, and
Codex eo titulo, l. pergit audacia , where also he who takes away the clothing of the dead or ornaments of the tomb is punished with the same penalty as a sacrilegist:
if with arms capitally, if without arms he is condemned to the mines.

According to the laws of the kingdom of Castile, the same is prohibited and punished by death, as is clear in
l. 1a titulo 18, libro 11o , where these words are placed:
He who breaks open the tomb of a dead person and takes anything from there shall die for it; and if he takes nothing he shall pay one hundred gold sueldos, half to the King and the other half to the relatives of the deceased.
Now each sueldo was worth one hundred and three gold pieces or ducats, as is had through
the gloss on l. 1am titulo 5 lib. 2o fori .

And because, from the gravity of the penalty which is inflicted in prohibition of some act, the gravity of the fault is argued, therefore whenever human laws prohibit some act under penalty of death or mutilation or condemnation to the mines, always doing the contrary is mortal sin according to the doctors and Saint Thomas, since human laws justly bind in the forum of conscience, because such a penalty is not inflicted except for what would be very harmful to justice and the good of the republic. It applies to
the aforesaid l. qui sepulchra Codex eo titulo , although there was little care, indeed none, by our magistrates in parts of the Indies to order the execution of such laws, where it is said:
Those who violate tombs, the houses (so to speak) of the dead, are seen to perpetrate a twofold crime. For they both despoil the buried by destroying and pollute the living by fabricating . They pollute, namely, by inflicting injury, etc.

The third part of the conclusion, namely that unless they restore the treasures and other precious things and all goods taken from the tombs to their proper owners or heirs and do penance for their sin, they cannot be saved, is clear from the preceding general conclusion with its proof. Nevertheless we wish to prove it again.
And it is argued first thus: No one can be saved without penance after mortal sin. But one detaining another's property and not restoring it does not do penance but feigns it, as
Augustine said to Macedonius
and is had in
d. c. si res . Therefore those who have taken or will take the aforesaid treasures from tombs without the license of the owners, unless they restore them to those to whom they pertain, will die impenitent and consequently it will be impossible to be saved.

Second it is argued thus: without observance of justice it is impossible for anyone to be saved. But those taking the aforesaid treasures and riches from another's tombs act against justice. Therefore, unless they restore them, which is an act of justice, it is impossible that they can be saved.

Third it is argued: it is impossible for anyone to be saved unless mortal sin is forgiven him. But to detain another's property even for a moment against the owner's will is a mortal sin just as to steal or seize, on account of which it is said in
Ecclesiasticus 21 :
Flee from sin as from the face of a serpent.
But those not restoring the aforesaid things which they steal or seize from tombs are always in mortal sin. Therefore, it is impossible for them to be saved.

Fourth: it is impossible for anyone who owes a debt of money to be saved if he does not return or pay it, just as through
the Apostle to the Romans 13 :
Render to all what is due, to whom tribute is due tribute, to whom tax tax, to whom honor honor, and owe nothing to anyone except to love one another . Whence having premised that debts should be rendered to all lest perhaps he seem to have said too little since this sounds like an affirmative precept, he added a negative:
owe nothing to anyone , as if to say:
You sin against God if you detain against his will what you owe to anyone . But those who despoil tombs and take treasures from there with the intention of keeping them for themselves against the owners' will are their debtors and are obliged to render them by divine precept. Therefore, if they do not render them, it is impossible for them to be saved.

Fifth it is argued: None of those who inflict any notable harm on a neighbor can be saved unless he repairs and removes it, since every harm inflicted on another is of itself repugnant to or contrary to charity, which is the life of the soul and moves to willing and doing the good of another. But all those who take the aforesaid treasures against the owners' will inflict notable harm, namely impeding them from enjoying and rejoicing in their goods and riches which were placed in those tombs for the honor, praise, and glory of themselves and their ancestors. Likewise they inflict on them another greater harm, which is that the memory of their parents and themselves perish. Similarly honor and praise and glory and name and fame in which they placed especially their whole interest and happiness
are extinguished. They are the cause, whence they injure them greatly. Therefore, unless through restitution of so many treasures taken against the owners' will they remove and repair such harms, it is impossible for them to be saved. For they lack charity and therefore have dead souls.

The fourth part of the conclusion is also proved, namely that for the injury which they inflict on the living and dead they are bound to repent and to make satisfaction as they are able. As regards repenting it is clear, since from their mortal sin of theft or plunder there follows in their neighbors that evil of injury, and this even if they did not have the intention of injuring but only of stealing or seizing treasures, because he who gives occasion for damage is seen to have given the damage itself,
c. si culpa de iniuriis et damno dato . But if they intended to inflict injury for the sake of diminishing honor or opinion,
beyond the sin, because it is against charity for neighbor whom we are bound to love as ourselves,
Matthew 22
and
8, questione 1, c. in scripturis
and
de penitentia, dist. 2, c. charitas el. 2o ,
Codex, de iniuriis, l. si non es nunciator .

Indeed as regards making satisfaction as one is able, by
d. c. si culpa , where it is said thus:
If by your fault damage was given or injury inflicted, or perhaps you gave aid to others inflicting them, or these things happened through your inexperience or negligence, by right it is necessary to make satisfaction for these things, nor does ignorance excuse you if you ought to have known that from your deed injury could most likely happen or loss.
Thus there. The reason for which is according to
Saint Thomas , who will be alleged below:
because restitution and satisfaction are distinct. For restitution is not part of satisfaction. And therefore a man harming a neighbor is not reconciled to him for an offense or injury through this, that he restores his things to him, but through this, that above this he shows him something of humility.

That moreover the aforesaid thieves or rather robbers or plunderers have committed injury and such loss is proved, because they take from the deceased their whole perpetual being, namely to live in the memory and opinions of men, and consequently they totally take away from the living honor, praise and glory. And this is a most atrocious injury to both, as in
instit. de iniuriis, § atrox . And this injury is so much graver as it redounds to more people. Just as that which is inflicted on a prince is graver than that on some private person, because it redounds to the injury of the whole multitude. Since therefore this injury redounds to the whole house, progeny or royal kinship of those kings and petty kings, indeed to the universal communities of their kingdoms, as appears from what has been said, and
argumentum de legatis 3, l. nutu, in fine ; and
argumentum 32, q. 7, capitulo offerebat , and disgrace is done to the whole kinship's splendor,
l. 1, Codex, de senatus consultis , closing by taking away. Therefore other things being equal, from this very fact such injury is greatly aggravated, on this
S. Thomas 2 2e q. 65 a. 4
and elsewhere. Whence for this injury inflicted not only all descendants and the whole royal kinship but also the universal communities of those kingdoms can act in their own name for injury against them,
ff. quando appellandum sit l. 2, § pen.
and
§ fine
and
De appellationibus, l. non tantum
and
de iniuriis, l. cum possit . For injury is done to the house, and there are three laws 1 and 2 and 3 most excellent for the proposition,
ff. de liberali causa
and
ff. Qui et aduersus quos, l. in fine .

Would it not be injurious among us to take away the standards, shields, insignia of nobles and magnates of Spain, and far more of kings, which they are accustomed to store in chapels of churches, and moreover tombs or monuments especially when they are covered with gold-woven or silk cloths or adorned with other precious furnishings or with golden or silver vessels? Certainly no one of the nobles of Spain at least (whatever it may be among other nations) would not bear it very ill and would not try as he is able to avenge this injury most fiercely, considering that his proper honor and the glory and praise and fame of his predecessors are greatly harmed. For that pertains (as has often been said) to the diminution or rather deletion of the honor and glory or fame of the living and dead. And this is a great interest of both. Therefore, it is necessary for those thus harming to make satisfaction for the injury beyond the necessary restitution.

And if it is acted upon juridically also civilly, it will stand by the oath of the living as regards estimation as legitimate proof, as is clear in
c. olim de iniuriis et damno dato
and
C. Unde vi, l. si quando
and
2, q. 1, c. in primis ; and
de his que ui met. cau. fi, c. ultimo . And the oath ought to be of this form:
We so-and-so swear that we would prefer to lose so many thousands of our own rather than to have suffered such an injury.
Moreover the estimation of injury increases or decreases according to the degree of dignity of the person suffering injury, as in
d. § attrox et § pena insti. de iniuriis . For it is manifest in our case that reasonably and probably anyone will judge that since those to whom the injury was inflicted were kings and great and most powerful and most wealthy lords, and they valued their tombs so highly on account of honor, praise, and glory, as things to be preferred to all wealth and preeminence even when dead, as is clear from what has been said, the estimation which they would make of the injuries which they have suffered in such matters from our people would not be just anything but thousands of thousands and hundreds of hundreds of thousands. Since truly such estimation among them and also among Philosophers and any wise men of this world has no comparison. Therefore there remains for such plunderers beyond the restitution of so many stolen treasures great satisfaction, and thus the way of being saved.

But if it is dealt with in the forum of conscience concerning such injuries, since they are not estimable with a price, they are bound to placate those thus harmed as much as would be possible for them, settling with them about the injuries done to them by themselves and humbly seeking pardon. And we ought to use this mode of satisfying especially whenever damage or injury inflicted on neighbors cannot be fully recompensed. These things are proved by
d. C. olim de iniuriis
and
S. Thomam 2 2e q. 62 articulo 2 ad 1m
and
ad 3m
and in
4 sententiarum dist. 18 q. 1 articulo 5 quaesticula 1a in corpore
and
ad 1m . And
hostiensis in summa titulo de iniuriis § contra quos detur
and
§ inquantum detur .
Raymundus and his gloss , and
Ulricus in summa confessorum, lib. 2 titul. 5 q. 65 .
The Holy Archbishop of Florence also in 2a parte titulo 2, c. 2, § 3 .
Astesanus similarly prima parte sue summe libro 2o titulo 14 .
Adrian finally in 4o speaking about restitution of reputation . And thus the fourth part of the conclusion is clear, and since the whole responsive conclusion to the question is sufficiently clear.

Likewise the law is in all respects the same concerning treasures and precious things if any are found in temples of idols which they venerated as their gods in their infidelity or idolatry, as concerning those which were placed in the tombs of their ancestors, namely that they did not hold them as abandoned things nor did they renounce ownership of them, nor now after their conversion are they vacant, but they have owners, namely either those who offered them to the idols in person if they survive or their heirs to whom it pertains to succeed by hereditary right according to their laws or customs.

This is proved because if they offered them to their false gods, this without doubt was understood to be offered under a tacit condition, namely if that or those to whom they sacrificed such things were the true god, and thus esteeming him the true god, since the intention of the gentiles especially tends principally and finally to worshipping the true God whom they know, although confusedly, naturally. Thus Jerome says on Psalm 95:
Thus both we and the whole human race naturally understand God. For there are no nations which do not naturally understand their creator. For although they venerate stones and wood, nevertheless they understand that something is greater than they are, and in their error they judge themselves to have wisdom, that is, there is no nation which does not naturally understand God. Finally the gentiles worship idols, that is they venerate stones and wood, and if perhaps they make a quarrel and if any oath comes among them, they do not say "these stones see," "the wood sees," but "God sees and God hears."
Thus Jerome in form.

A certain Roman idolater, a grammarian named Maximus, writing to Augustine, strove to show this same thing:
Indeed (he says) who so demented, so captive in mind, would deny it to be most certain that there is one God without beginning, without offspring of nature, or a great and magnificent father? We invoke his powers diffused through the work of the world with many names, since we all are ignorant of his proper name. For God is a name common to all religions. Thus it happens that while we pursue as it were certain members of him piecemeal with various supplications, we are seen to worship the whole
etc. Thus he in the epistle which is numbered among
Augustine's epistles as 43 . Since therefore they offered to others who were not gods, esteeming that they were offering to the true God so that they might worship and venerate him, after now by God's grace they have received the faith and know that they were deceived in doing this, it is manifest that they can recover and reclaim those things, since they did not place them there with that mind, thinking through error that they were gods, with a tacit or implicit condition that if they were not true gods or god, in no way would they otherwise have offered them, and consequently they did not lose ownership of those things. This is clear in one who gives what is not owed by all right to one through ignorance or error, thinking to give to another, since error excludes his free will. For every error induces repetition, and thus it is understood indistinctly,
l. cuius per errorem, ff, de regulis iuris
and
Codex, De conditione indebiti, l. 1 , and
l. cum et soluta , and
through that whole title
and
ff.
and through the whole and
Codex de iure et facti ignorantia, L. cum quis , where
a great gloss is noted in cap. finali de solutione . Since therefore with a tacit condition, although not excusing, every idolater is seen to worship idols, thinking through error that he venerates the true God and offers to him his immolations or sacrifices, to which sacrifices in common natural reason they see themselves to be obliged — which if they knew they erred, natural reason itself would draw them back from idolatry — it follows manifestly that through error they placed those precious things unowed in temples to the honor of false gods, certainly not going to place them if they knew the error, and therefore there is no doubt that, as we said, they can reclaim them. Since just as knowing the error they would not offer them, so without doubt they would not cast away their ownership of them. Therefore they are still their owners, and they can reclaim them as their own things. This will also able to be confirmed through an example of this kind: Let a case be given within our Christian religion that some Christian was in such error that he thought that those things which he offered in church to the honor of God and for celebrating divine worship — chalices and other vessels either golden or silver or gold-woven or silken — did not please God and would profit him nothing after this life, it seems manifest that he would surely not have cast away ownership of those things from himself in his intention nor held them as abandoned things. Since even if he offered them in church so that divine worship would be celebrated honorably, this however presupposing a tacit and implicit condition if they pleased God and so that he might receive a reward in the other life, otherwise certainly he would not have offered them in vain, reason itself compels us to understand. But if, by the impossible, that error were confirmed by someone to whose authority and faith deference should deservedly be given, there would be no one of the gentile philosophers having judgment of prudence, if he were constituted judge of this controversy, who judging justly would not decree those offered goods to be restored to him as proper and having ownership of them.

It appears therefore no less, or by equal and perhaps stronger reason, that treasures and other riches and precious furnishings which are found and have been found or will be found in future time in the temples formerly of idols and were offered in honor of the gods in the time of their infidelity pertain to those who offered them or their heirs, just as those which are or will be found or discovered in tombs.
